body: They came despite the snow and slush, most straight from work, some after multiple bus trips, demanding to know whether anything could be done to save Canarsie High School. A few days earlier, the city's Education Department announced that Canarsie was in such disarray that the only way to fix it would be to shut it down, replacing it with several
title: At Canarsie High, Now Marked for Closing, Loyalty Prevails

body: A woman was found dead and two men were seriously injured last night in a suspicious fire at a New York City Housing Authority project in the East New York area, the police and fire officials said. The fire broke out on the fifth floor of an eight-story brick apartment building at 730 Euclid Avenue near Dumont Avenue in the Cypress Hills complex.
title: METRO BRIEFING | NEW YORK; Brooklyn: Woman Dies In Suspicious Fire

body: AROUND TOWN HARLEM WEEK Now in its 33rd year, the month of festivities known as Harlem Week continues on Sunday with a full day of events. ''A Great Day in Harlem'' begins at noon in Ulysses S. Grant National Memorial Park, with performances from Broadway and Off Broadway plays; an excerpt from ''Lady Sings the Blues,'' featuring blues and jazz
title: Spare Times

body: AROUND TOWN Museums and Sites AMERICAN MUSEUM OF NATURAL HISTORY Central Park West and 79th Street. Through Aug. 19, ''Gold,'' with coins, jewelry and other artifacts. Through Sept. 9, ''Frogs: A Chorus of Colors,'' an exhibition of more than 200 specimens. Through Jan. 6, ''Mythic Creatures: Dragons, Unicorns and Mermaids.'' Through April 6,
title: Around Town

body: After executing 19 search warrants early yesterday in the Cypress Hills Houses in East New York, the police said they had arrested 53 people, including 23 women, on charges of selling crack cocaine or heroin. The sweep was conducted at a public housing project that has long been plagued by illegal drugs. Eighty people were arrested there on similar
title: Metro Briefing | New York: Brooklyn: 53 Face Drug Charges

author: David McAninch is a deputy editor at Saveur magazine.
body: NO one answered the buzzer at 964 Jamaica Avenue. A locksmith's calling card and a KeySpan service notice protruded from the doorframe and fluttered in the breeze, just beneath the sign that read ''Taxidermist.'' Frozen eerily behind a vitrine above the boarded-up storefront were a lifelike fox, a hawk of some sort, and what appeared to be a couple
title: A Road Not Taken, Much

body: MORE than four million people have passed through the gleaming glass transit hub in Howard Beach, in far southeastern Queens, since it opened in December 2003, with the purpose of catching a light-rail AirTrain to or from Kennedy International Airport. Some, fresh to New York, have also undoubtedly peered through the station windows, eager for
title: LIVING IN/Howard Beach, Queens; Prices Aren't Supersonic; the Planes Aren't Either

body: For Pat Russo, the corner of the Sunset Park Recreation Center where he founded a free boxing program two decades ago is haunted by the sounds of youthful ambition: the shuffle of fast-moving feet, the grunts of landed punches, the shouts of ''Jab, jab!'' by hawk-eyed coaches. Today the ring is gone, the corner mostly silent. Once offered as an
title: Where Friendly Punches Flew in Brooklyn, Clubs Lose to Rising Rents

body: In the 75th Precinct, in the East New York section of Brooklyn, which has the city's highest violent crime rate and some of its poorest neighborhoods, the police stopped, questioned or frisked someone last year, on average, about once every 24 minutes. Meanwhile, in the First Precinct, which encompasses Battery Park, Wall Street, TriBeCa and SoHo,
title: Numbers Show How Police Work Varies by Precinct

body: Sally Mae Jenkins is full of stories. In a breathless rasp, she recalls traipsing through the woods of her native South Carolina, running from snakes and getting into dicey escapades with her 13 brothers and sisters. Then she talks of having a daughter at 17, only to lose her 25 years later. Each reverie is delivered in her thick-as-molasses
title: The Neediest Cases; A Warm Coat for a Woman With Endless Stories to Tell
